newsitem.title: USA: Fitch's upgrade of Detroit wins praise from mayor.
newsitem.headline: Fitch's upgrade of Detroit wins praise from mayor.

text.p: Fitch Investors Service raised Detroit's general obligation debt rating to BBB on Thursday, citing its improved financial condition, a decision hailed by the city's mayor, Dennis Archer.
"I'm very pleased to learn of our third straight debt rating upgrade," Archer said in a statement. "Detroit is on solid fiscal footing, and our best days are ahead of us."
Fitch raised Detroit's general obligation debt rating from BBB-minus to BBB. This is the third upgrade of Detroit debt in the last week by a major rating agency.

In its statement, Fitch said Detroit's financial condition had improved demonstrably, with sluggish revenue growth and net operating deficits giving way to economic expansion and financial improvement.

However, the rating agency warned that Detroit continued to face risks. The challenges include its significant debt burden, its ability to manage through an economic downturn, and its revenue vulnerability.

The Fitch upgrade followed an October 22 announcement by Standard & Poor's Corp that its credit outlook on Detroit had changed from stable to positive. Moody's Investors Service Inc raised Detroit's general obligation debt rating from Ba1 to Baa on October 17.
